query: What are the requirements for ICT risk management and incident reporting under DORA?
answer:
Below are the requirements in the provided DORA text for ICT risk management and ICT-related incident management/reporting.

1) ICT risk management (general / simplified framework for certain small entities)
- Entities exempted from Articles 5–15 must nevertheless "put in place and maintain a sound and documented ICT risk management framework" detailing mechanisms and measures for quick, efficient and comprehensive ICT risk management, including protection of physical components/infrastructure [DORA Article 16 / Article 16 / 1 (second subparagraph) (a)].
- They must continuously monitor security/functioning of ICT systems [DORA Article 16 / Article 16 / 1 (second subparagraph) (b)] and minimise ICT risk impact by using sound, resilient and updated ICT systems, protocols and tools to protect availability, authenticity, integrity and confidentiality of data [DORA Article 16 / Article 16 / 1 (second subparagraph) (c)].
- They must allow prompt identification/detection of ICT risk sources and anomalies and swift handling of ICT-related incidents [DORA Article 16 / Article 16 / 1 (second subparagraph) (d)].
- Identify key dependencies on ICT third‑party service providers [DORA Article 16 / Article 16 / 1 (second subparagraph) (e)].
- Ensure continuity of critical/important functions through business continuity plans and response/recovery measures (including back-up and restoration) [DORA Article 16 / Article 16 / 1 (second subparagraph) (f)] and test those plans and the effectiveness of controls on a regular basis [DORA Article 16 / Article 16 / 1 (second subparagraph) (g)].
- Implement operational conclusions from tests and post‑incident analysis, and develop awareness/training as appropriate [DORA Article 16 / Article 16 / 1 (second subparagraph) (h)].
- The ICT risk management framework must be documented, reviewed periodically and after major ICT-related incidents, continuously improved, and a report on its review provided to the competent authority upon request [DORA Article 16 / Article 16 / 2].
- The ESAs, via the Joint Committee and consulting ENISA, shall develop draft RTS to further specify elements of the framework, systems/protocols/tools, business continuity components and testing, and report format [DORA Article 16 / Article 16 / 3].

2) ICT-related incident management and reporting (Article 17) — required processes and elements
- Financial entities must define, establish and implement an ICT-related incident management process to detect, manage and notify ICT-related incidents [DORA Article 17 / Article 17 / 1].
- Entities must record all ICT-related incidents and significant cyber threats, and establish procedures/processes for consistent, integrated monitoring, handling and follow-up so that root causes are identified, documented and addressed to prevent recurrence [DORA Article 17 / Article 17 / 2].
- The incident management process must:
  - include early warning indicators [DORA Article 17 / Article 17 / 3 (a)];
  - establish procedures to identify, track, log, categorise and classify ICT-related incidents according to priority/severity and the criticality of impacted services (in line with criteria in Article 18(1)) [DORA Article 17 / Article 17 / 3 (b)];
  - assign roles and responsibilities to be activated for different incident types/scenarios [DORA Article 17 / Article 17 / 3 (c)];
  - set out communication plans to staff, external stakeholders and media (in accordance with Article 14), notifications to clients, internal escalation procedures (including customer complaints), and provision of information to counterpart financial entities as appropriate [DORA Article 17 / Article 17 / 3 (d)];
  - ensure that at least major ICT-related incidents are reported to relevant senior management and that the management body is informed of at least major incidents, explaining impact, response and additional controls to be established [DORA Article 17 / Article 17 / 3 (e)];
  - establish incident response procedures to mitigate impacts and ensure services become operational and secure in a timely manner [DORA Article 17 / Article 17 / 3 (f)].

3) Communication requirements (Article 14) relevant to incident reporting
- Entities must have crisis communication plans enabling responsible disclosure of, at least, major ICT-related incidents or vulnerabilities to clients and counterparts and to the public, as appropriate [DORA Article 14 / Article 14 / 1].
- Entities must implement communication policies for internal staff and external stakeholders, differentiating staff involved in ICT risk management/response from other staff who need to be informed [DORA Article 14 / Article 14 / 2].
- At least one person must be tasked with implementing the communication strategy for ICT-related incidents and fulfil the public/media function [DORA Article 14 / Article 14 / 3].

Note: Specific details not included in the provided chunks — for example, precise reporting thresholds, timelines, or the full classification criteria in Article 18 and any obligations to notify authorities — are not present in the retrieved sources. Information not available in retrieved sources.
